title: Hub Arkush: Bears' loss to Detroit Lions a reminder of where Chicago stands
text:
Hub Arkush: Bears' loss to Detroit Lions a reminder of where Chicago stands Published: Sunday, Oct. 18, 2015 9:41 p.m. CDT Caption Hub Arkush By HUB ARKUSH - harkush@chicagofootball.com 
Watching the Lions’ 37-34 overtime win over the Bears on Sunday was absolutely akin to kissing your sister. 
In a game neither team deserved to win, the tallest little person prevailed. 
The unknown going in was whether or not the Lions would show up at all at 0-5, and the answer turned out to be they would come and go during various points in the game. 
What Detroit did well enough to win was limit the Bears to points on only three of their eight visits inside the red zone, and the team that came in dead last in the NFL in rushing, ground out 155 yards on 32 carries against the Bears, a 4.8 average. 
A lot of Bears did a lot of good things on offense against the Lions as the Bears piled up 444 yards and 24 first downs, but almost every one of them made key mistakes, as well. 
Bears quarterback Jay Cutler was very, very good again (26 for 41, 353 yards, 1 TD, 1 INT, and two runs for 12 yards), but his interception in the end zone on the Bears’ opening drive of the second half, while trailing 21-13, was extremely costly. 
Tight end Martellus Bennett and receiver Marquess Wilson continue to make big plays here and there, but each had costly drops on what should have been sure catches. 
The Bears’ rebuilt offensive line did a nice job protecting Cutler, but the running game was limited to 91 yards on 31 rushes, a 2.9 average, mainly because of the Lions’ defensive front dominating the line of scrimmage most of the day. 
The Bears’ defense struggled in the front seven as shown by the Lions’ success on the ground, but it’s worth asking how much of that was because of the absence of middle lineback Shea McClellin and defensive lineman Ego Ferguson. 
Much was being made of the Bears’ improvement from 31st in the NFL last year in total defense to fourth in the coming into the Lions game, but they still were 28th in points allowed before Sunday’s game, and both of those stats will take a serious hit after allowing the Lions 37 points and 546 yards of offense. 
If there were any glaring problems with the Bears on Sunday, it definitely was in the secondary. 
Tracy Porter got beat a few times trying to man up on Calvin Johnson, so welcome to the club. For the most part, Porter really wasn’t bad. The rest of the secondary was. 
Sherrick McManis is a wonderful special teams player who clearly won the nickel cornerback job in training camp, but that has to change after Sunday. 
He has struggled since the opener against the Packers, and left Detroit with first-degree burns courtesy of Golden Tate and Lance Moore. 
The other player we have to question going into the bye week is Kyle Fuller. He seemed to be settling down a bit after a really rough start in the Bears’ first three losses, but he took a huge step backward Sunday. 
Fuller is willing to come up and stick his nose in on the run and bubble screens, but once he has to play on the backpedal or with his back to the quarterback, he’s toast. More than anything, the Bears’ loss was a wakeup call and reminder to Bears fans about where their beloved really stand in the NFL’s current pecking order. 
The Bears went into Detroit three-point underdogs and got beat by three points. None of the reasons for Bears fans optimism coming off the two-game winning streak changed. 
Cutler was very good again, Alshon Jeffery made a really strong return from his hamstring injury, the young offensive linemen certainly weren’t the reason the Bears lost and Eddie Goldman, Christian Jones and Adrian Amos grew up a little more at Ford Field. 
On the flip side, the Bears still need another receiver, probably two, and they still have a clear talent deficit on all three levels of the defense, most glaringly at inside linebacker and in the secondary. 
Much of that won’t change until the offseason, but right now, this team is learning and competing, and after last year, that’s not all bad.
